bestBHT.bht: The Jews from Thessalonica came to Berea and stirred up the people, causing a whirlwind of excitement. This tumultuous attack reflects the depth and intensity of the hatred towards Paul. The figure of troubled waves of the sea is used to describe the agitation and excitement of the popular tumult. These pursuits reveal Satan's desperate malice to destroy the kingdom of Christ. It is a reminder that even today, faithful ministers face furious enemies instigated by Satan to undermine the work of Christ.

Henry Alford: From the distance, some time must have elapsed before this could take place.
All that was known at Berœa of his intended route was, that it was in the direction of the sea.
Where he embarked for Athens, is not said: probably at Dium, near the base of Mount Olympus.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: came thither also—"like hunters upon their prey, as they
had done before from Iconium to Lystra" [HOWSON].
Albert Barnes: Stirred up the people - The word used here σαλεύειν saleuein denotes properly 'to agitate' or 'excite,' as the waves of the sea are agitated by the wind."
It is with great beauty used to denote the 'agitation and excitement of a popular tumult,' from its resemblance to the troubled waves of the ocean.
The figure is often employed by the Classic writers, and also occurs in the Scriptures.
Marvin Vincent: They that conducted [καθιστωντες] . Lit., brought to the spot. Note the different word employed, ch. 14 3 (see note there).
John Calvin: We must not so much in this place consider the fury of the nation as the desperate malice of Satan, who pricketh forward those which be his to trouble the kingdom of Christ, and to destroy man’s salvation.

When at this day so many furious enemies do set themselves against the faithful ministers of Christ, it is not men which procure the war, but it is Satan, the father of lying, who doth go about all these things that he may overthrow the kingdom of Christ.
Satan will never cease to make weary those whom he knoweth to serve Christ faithfully, either with open war, or secret lying in wait, or domestical combats.
Philip Schaff: These short notices in the ‘Acts’ of the steady, unwearied pursuit of Paul from city to city give us a hint at least of that restless bitter hatred with which this great Gentile apostle was regarded by the majority of his countrymen.
A hate the depth and intensity of which the critical studies of this age is only beginning to fathom.
The critical studies of this age is only beginning to fathom the depth and intensity of the hatred towards Apostle Paul.
Archibald T. Robertson: Stirring the crowds like an earthquake and disturbing like a tornado.
The attack was sharp and swift.
This quiet and noble town was in a whirl of excitement over the attacks of the Jewish emissaries from Thessalonica.
John Gill: But when the Jews of Thessalonica,.... The unbelieving Jews there,
had knowledge that the word of God was preached of Paul at Berea...
...and stirred up the people; the common people, the natives of the place, against the apostles; suggesting that they were wicked men, and enemies to all laws, human or divine, civil or religious.

bhtAttempts.bht: The incident in Acts 17:13 where the Jews from Thessalonica came to stir up the people in Berea is described as the actions of hunters upon their prey. This tumultuous attack by the Jewish emissaries caused a whirlwind of excitement in the quiet and noble town of Berea. The agitation and excitement of the popular tumult can be compared to the troubled waves of the sea. These relentless pursuits of Paul from city to city highlight the depth and intensity of the hatred towards him, which is driven by Satan's desperate malice to destroy the kingdom of Christ and undermine man's salvation. The actions of the Jews in Thessalonica were not merely a result of their own fury, but were instigated by Satan himself. This passage serves as a reminder that even today, when faithful ministers of Christ are met with furious enemies, it is Satan who orchestrates these attacks to undermine the work of Christ.

The Jews from Thessalonica, like hunters upon their prey, came to Berea and swiftly stirred up the people, causing a whirlwind of excitement. Their agitating attack reflects the desperate malice of Satan, who incites enemies against faithful ministers of Christ. The intensity of their hatred towards Apostle Paul, catalogued in the Acts, reveals the depth and extent of their opposition to the spread of the Gospel. This passage serves as a chilling reminder of the relentless attacks orchestrated by Satan to undermine the kingdom of Christ.

The arrival of the Jews from Thessalonica to Berea caused a swift and sharp attack, stirring up the people and creating an atmosphere of excitement. This barrage of opposition against Paul, driven by deep-seated hatred, reveals the relentless pursuit and intense animosity he faced. Such aggression and hostility were not simply a result of human fury, but rather the desperate malice of Satan himself, seeking to undermine the work and purpose of the kingdom of Christ.
